class.name: FastMath

javadoc.text:
Faster, more accurate, portable alternative to {@link Math} and{@link StrictMath} for large scale computation. *

* FastMath is a drop-in replacement for both Math and StrictMath. This * means that for any method in Math (say {@code Math.sin(x)} or{@code Math.cbrt(y)}), user can directly change the class and use the * methods as is (using {@code FastMath.sin(x)} or {@code FastMath.cbrt(y)}in the previous example). *

*

* FastMath speed is achieved by relying heavily on optimizing compilers * to native code present in many JVMs today and use of large tables. * The larger tables are lazily initialised on first use, so that the setup * time does not penalise methods that don't need them. *

*

* Note that FastMath is * extensively used inside Apache Commons Math, so by calling some algorithms, * the overhead when the the tables need to be intialised will occur * regardless of the end-user calling FastMath methods directly or not. * Performance figures for a specific JVM and hardware can be evaluated by * running the FastMathTestPerformance tests in the test directory of the source * distribution. *

*

* FastMath accuracy should be mostly independent of the JVM as it relies only * on IEEE-754 basic operations and on embedded tables. Almost all operations * are accurate to about 0.5 ulp throughout the domain range. This statement, * of course is only a rough global observed behavior, it is not a * guarantee for every double numbers input (see William Kahan's Table * Maker's Dilemma). *

*

* FastMath additionally implements the following methods not found in Math/StrictMath: *

    *
  • {@link #asinh(double)}
    • *
  • {@link #acosh(double)}
    • *
  • {@link #atanh(double)}
    • *
* The following methods are found in Math/StrictMath since 1.6 only, they are provided * by FastMath even in 1.5 Java virtual machines *
    *
  • {@link #copySign(double,double)}
    • *
  • {@link #getExponent(double)}
    • *
  • {@link #nextAfter(double,double)}
    • *
  • {@link #nextUp(double)}
    • *
  • {@link #scalb(double,int)}
    • *
  • {@link #copySign(float,float)}
    • *
  • {@link #getExponent(float)}
    • *
  • {@link #nextAfter(float,double)}
    • *
  • {@link #nextUp(float)}
    • *
  • {@link #scalb(float,int)}
    • *
*

* This compile-time constant should be set to true only if one explicitly * wants to compute the tables at class loading time instead of using the * already computed ones provided as literal arrays below. *

Coefficients for log in the range of 1.0 < x < 1.0 + 2^-10.

javadoc.text:
Returns a pseudo-random number between 0.0 and 1.0. *

Note: this implementation currently delegates to {@link Math#random}

Exponential function. * Computes exp(x), function result is nearly rounded. It will be correctly * rounded to the theoretical value for 99.9% of input values, otherwise it will * have a 1 UPL error. * Method: * Lookup intVal = exp(int(x)) * Lookup fracVal = exp(int(x-int(x) / 1024.0) * 1024.0 ); * Compute z as the exponential of the remaining bits by a polynomial minus one * exp(x) = intVal * fracVal * (1 + z) * Accuracy: * Calculation is done with 63 bits of precision, so result should be correctly * rounded for 99.9% of input values, with less than 1 ULP error otherwise.
javadoc.param: x a double

javadoc.text: Internal helper method for exponential function.
javadoc.param: x original argument of the exponential function
extra extra bits of precision on input (To Be Confirmed)
hiPrec extra bits of precision on output (To Be Confirmed)

method.name: exp
method.comment: Lookup exp(floor(x)). intPartA will have the upper 22 bits, intPartB will have the lower 52 bits.
This will produce a subnormal output
exp(1.494140625) is nearly a machine number...
Get the fractional part of x, find the greatest multiple of 2^-10 less than x and look up the exp function of it. fracPartA will have the upper 22 bits, fracPartB the lower 52 bits.
epsilon is the difference in x from the nearest multiple of 2^-10. It has a value in the range 0 <= epsilon < 2^-10. Do the subtraction from x as the last step to avoid possible loss of percison.

Compute z = exp(epsilon) - 1.0 via a minimax polynomial. z has full double precision (52 bits). Since z < 2^-10, we will have 62 bits of precision when combined with the contant 1. This will be used in the last addition below to get proper rounding.
Remez generated polynomial. Converges on the interval [0, 2^-10], error is less than 0.5 ULP
Compute (intPartA+intPartB) (fracPartA+fracPartB) by binomial expansion. tempA is exact since intPartA and intPartB only have 22 bits each. tempB will have 52 bits of precision.

Compute the result. (1+z)(tempA+tempB). Order of operations is important. For accuracy add by increasing size. tempA is exact and much larger than the others. If there are extra bits specified from the pow() function, use them.

javadoc.text: Compute exp(x) - 1
javadoc.param: x number to compute shifted exponential

javadoc.text: Internal helper method for expm1
javadoc.param: x number to compute shifted exponential
hiPrecOut receive high precision result for -1.0 < x < 1.0

method.name: expm1
method.comment: Combine the parts. expm1(a+b) = expm1(a) + expm1(b) + expm1(a)expm1(b)
yb += (ya > za) ? -(temp - ya - za) : -(temp - za - ya);
yb += (ya > baseB) ? -(temp - ya - baseB) : -(temp - baseB - ya);
yb += (ya > zb) ? -(temp - ya - zb) : -(temp - zb - ya);

Handle special cases of Positive infinity.
The normal method doesn't work well in the range [0.99, 1.01], so call do a straight polynomial expansion in higer precision.
lnm is a log of a number in the range of 1.0 - 2.0, so 0 <= lnm < ln(2)
y is the most significant 10 bits of the mantissa
Need a more accurate epsilon, so adjust the division.
High precision not required. Eval Remez polynomial using standard double precision
Compute the following sum: lnzb + lnm[1] + ln2Bexp + lnza + lnm[0] + ln2Aexp;
return lnzb + lnm[1] + ln2B*exp + lnza + lnm[0] + ln2A*exp;

javadoc.text: Computes the * logarithm in a given base. * Returns {@code NaN} if either argument is negative. * If {@code base} is 0 and {@code x} is positive, 0 is returned. * If {@code base} is positive and {@code x} is 0,{@code Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY} is returned. * If both arguments are 0, the result is {@code NaN}.
javadoc.param: base Base of the logarithm, must be greater than 0.
x Argument, must be greater than 0.
javadoc.return: the value of the logarithm, i.e. the number {@code y} such that * basey = x.

method.name: pow
method.comment: split d as two 26 bits numbers
beware the following expressions must NOT be simplified, they rely on floating point arithmetic properties
accurate multiplication result = result * d^(2p) using Veltkamp TwoProduct algorithm
beware the following expressions must NOT be simplified, they rely on floating point arithmetic properties
accurate squaring d^(2(p+1)) = d^(2p) * d^(2p) using Veltkamp TwoProduct algorithm
beware the following expressions must NOT be simplified, they rely on floating point arithmetic properties

javadoc.param: x a number smaller than 1/16

xb extra bits for x (may be 0.0)

method.name: sinQ
method.comment: Compute sin(x) by angle addition formula

Compute the following sum:
result = sintA + costAsinEpsA + sintAcosEpsB + costAsinEpsB + sintB + costBsinEpsA + sintBcosEpsB + costBsinEpsB;
Ranges of elements
xxxtA 0 PI2 xxxtB -1.5e-9 1.5e-9 sinEpsA -0.0625 0.0625 sinEpsB -6e-11 6e-11 cosEpsA 1.0 cosEpsB 0 -0.0625
result = sintA + sintA*cosEpsB + sintB + sintB * cosEpsB;
result += costA*sinEpsA + costA*sinEpsB + costB*sinEpsA + costB * sinEpsB;

javadoc.text: Compute cosine in the first quadrant by subtracting input from PI/2 and * then calling sinQ. This is more accurate as the input approaches PI/2.
javadoc.param: xa number from which cosine is requested
xb extra bits for x (may be 0.0)

javadoc.text: Compute tangent (or cotangent) over the first quadrant. 0 < x < pi/2 * Use combination of table lookup and rational polynomial expansion.
javadoc.param: xa number from which sine is requested
xb extra bits for x (may be 0.0)
cotanFlag if true, compute the cotangent instead of the tangent

method.name: tanQ
method.comment: Compute sin(x) by angle addition formula

Compute the following sum:
result = sintA + costAsinEpsA + sintAcosEpsB + costAsinEpsB + sintB + costBsinEpsA + sintBcosEpsB + costBsinEpsB;
Ranges of elements
xxxtA 0 PI2 xxxtB -1.5e-9 1.5e-9 sinEpsA -0.0625 0.0625 sinEpsB -6e-11 6e-11 cosEpsA 1.0 cosEpsB 0 -0.0625
result = sintA + sintA*cosEpsB + sintB + sintB * cosEpsB;
result += costA*sinEpsA + costA*sinEpsB + costB*sinEpsA + costB * sinEpsB;
Split the estimate to get more accurate read on division rounding
double err = (sina - est*cosa)/cosa; Correction for division rounding
Change in est due to sinb
Change in est due to cosb

javadoc.text: Reduce the input argument using the Payne and Hanek method. * This is good for all inputs 0.0 < x < inf * Output is remainder after dividing by PI/2 * The result array should contain 3 numbers. * result[0] is the integer portion, so mod 4 this gives the quadrant. * result[1] is the upper bits of the remainder * result[2] is the lower bits of the remainder
javadoc.param: x number to reduce
result placeholder where to put the result

method.name: reducePayneHanek
method.comment: Normalize input to be between 0.5 and 1.0
Based on the exponent, get a shifted copy of recip2pi

prodA, prodB now contain the remainder as a fraction of PI. We want this as a fraction of PI2, so use the following steps: 1.) multiply by 4. 2.) do a fixed point muliply by PI4. 3.) Convert to floating point. 4.) Multiply by 2

method.name: atan
method.comment: Estimate the closest tabulated arctan value, compute eps = xa-tangentTable
If the slope of the arctan is gentle enough (< 0.45), this approximation will suffice
double denom = 1.0 / (1.0 + xa*tangentTableA[idx] + xb*tangentTableA[idx] + xa*tangentTableB[idx] + xb*tangentTableB[idx]);
Add in effect of epsB. atan'(x) = 1(1+x^2)
Result is in the left plane

Estimate the cube root of mant by polynomial
est should now be good to about 15 bits of precision. Do 2 rounds of
Newton's method to get closer, this should get us full double precision
Scale down x for the purpose of doing newtons method. This avoids over/under flows.
Do one round of Newton's method in extended precision to get the last bit right.
Scale by a power of two, so this is exact.

javadoc.param: d number to multiply
n power of 2

method.name: scalb
method.comment: first simple and fast handling when 2^n can be represented using normal numbers
we are really in the case n <= -1023
both the input and the result are normal numbers, we only adjust the exponent
the input is a normal number and the result is a subnormal number
scales down complete mantissa, hence losing least significant bits
we need to add 1 bit to round up the result
no need to compute the mantissa, the number scales down to 0
we are really in the case n >= 1024
the input number is subnormal, normalize it

javadoc.text: Multiply a float number by a power of 2.
javadoc.param: f number to multiply
n power of 2

method.name: scalb
method.comment: first simple and fast handling when 2^n can be represented using normal numbers
we are really in the case n <= -127
both the input and the result are normal numbers, we only adjust the exponent
the input is a normal number and the result is a subnormal number
scales down complete mantissa, hence losing least significant bits
we need to add 1 bit to round up the result
no need to compute the mantissa, the number scales down to 0
we are really in the case n >= 128
the input number is subnormal, normalize it

javadoc.text:
Get the next machine representable number after a number, moving * in the direction of another number. *

* The ordering is as follows (increasing): *

    *
  • -INFINITY
    • *
  • -MAX_VALUE
    • *
  • -MIN_VALUE
    • *
  • -0.0
    • *
  • +0.0
    • *
  • +MIN_VALUE
    • *
  • +MAX_VALUE
    • *
  • +INFINITY
    • *
  • *

    * If arguments compare equal, then the second argument is returned. *

    * If {@code direction} is greater than {@code d}, * the smallest machine representable number strictly greater than{@code d} is returned; if less, then the largest representable number * strictly less than {@code d} is returned.

    *

    * If {@code d} is infinite and direction does not * bring it back to finite numbers, it is returned unchanged.
javadoc.param: d base number
direction (the only important thing is whether{@code direction} is greater or smaller than {@code d})
javadoc.return: the next machine representable number in the specified direction

method.name: nextAfter
method.comment: handling of some important special cases
special cases MAX_VALUE to infinity and MIN_VALUE to 0
are handled just as normal numbers
can use raw bits since already dealt with infinity and NaN

javadoc.text:
Get the next machine representable number after a number, moving * in the direction of another number. *

* The ordering is as follows (increasing): *

    *
  • -INFINITY
    • *
  • -MAX_VALUE
    • *
  • -MIN_VALUE
    • *
  • -0.0
    • *
  • +0.0
    • *
  • +MIN_VALUE
    • *
  • +MAX_VALUE
    • *
  • +INFINITY
    • *
  • *

    * If arguments compare equal, then the second argument is returned. *

    * If {@code direction} is greater than {@code f}, * the smallest machine representable number strictly greater than{@code f} is returned; if less, then the largest representable number * strictly less than {@code f} is returned.

    *

    * If {@code f} is infinite and direction does not * bring it back to finite numbers, it is returned unchanged.
javadoc.param: f base number
direction (the only important thing is whether{@code direction} is greater or smaller than {@code f})
javadoc.return: the next machine representable number in the specified direction

method.name: nextAfter
method.comment: handling of some important special cases
special cases MAX_VALUE to infinity and MIN_VALUE to 0
are handled just as normal numbers

javadoc.text:
Returns the hypotenuse of a triangle with sides {@code x} and {@code y}- sqrt(x2 +y2)
* avoiding intermediate overflow or underflow. *
    *
  • If either argument is infinite, then the result is positive infinity.
    • *
  • else, if either argument is NaN then the result is NaN.
    • *
javadoc.param: x a value
y a value

method.name: hypot
method.comment: y is neglectible with respect to x
x is neglectible with respect to y
find an intermediate scale to avoid both overflow and underflow

javadoc.text:
Computes the remainder as prescribed by the IEEE 754 standard. * The remainder value is mathematically equal to {@code x - y*n}where {@code n} is the mathematical integer closest to the exact mathematical value * of the quotient {@code x/y}. * If two mathematical integers are equally close to {@code x/y} then{@code n} is the integer that is even. *

*

    *
  • If either operand is NaN, the result is NaN.
    • *
  • If the result is not NaN, the sign of the result equals the sign of the dividend.
    • *
  • If the dividend is an infinity, or the divisor is a zero, or both, the result is NaN.
    • *
  • If the dividend is finite and the divisor is an infinity, the result equals the dividend.
    • *
  • If the dividend is a zero and the divisor is finite, the result equals the dividend.
    • *
*

Note: this implementation currently delegates to {@link StrictMath#IEEEremainder}
javadoc.param: dividend the number to be divided
divisor the number by which to divide

javadoc.text: Returns the first argument with the sign of the second argument. * A NaN {@code sign} argument is treated as positive.
javadoc.param: magnitude the value to return
sign the sign for the returned value
javadoc.return: the magnitude with the same sign as the {@code sign} argument

method.name: copySign
method.comment: The highest order bit is going to be zero if the
highest order bit of m and s is the same and one otherwise.
So (m^s) will be positive if both m and s have the same sign

javadoc.text: Returns the first argument with the sign of the second argument. * A NaN {@code sign} argument is treated as positive.
javadoc.param: magnitude the value to return
sign the sign for the returned value
javadoc.return: the magnitude with the same sign as the {@code sign} argument

method.name: copySign
method.comment: The highest order bit is going to be zero if the
highest order bit of m and s is the same and one otherwise.
So (m^s) will be positive if both m and s have the same sign

javadoc.text:
Return the exponent of a double number, removing the bias. *

* For double numbers of the form 2x, the unbiased * exponent is exactly x. *
javadoc.param: d number from which exponent is requested
javadoc.return: exponent for d in IEEE754 representation, without bias

method.name: getExponent
method.comment: NaN and Infinite will return 1024 anywho so can use raw bits

javadoc.text:
Return the exponent of a float number, removing the bias. *

* For float numbers of the form 2x, the unbiased * exponent is exactly x. *
javadoc.param: f number from which exponent is requested
javadoc.return: exponent for d in IEEE754 representation, without bias

method.name: getExponent
method.comment: NaN and Infinite will return the same exponent anywho so can use raw bits

javadoc.text:
Print out contents of arrays, and check the length. *

used to generate the preset arrays originally.
javadoc.param: a unused

javadoc.text: Enclose large data table in nested static class so it's only loaded on first access.
Exponential evaluated at integer values, * exp(x) = expIntTableA[x + EXP_INT_TABLE_MAX_INDEX] + expIntTableB[x+EXP_INT_TABLE_MAX_INDEX].
Exponential evaluated at integer values, * exp(x) = expIntTableA[x + EXP_INT_TABLE_MAX_INDEX] + expIntTableB[x+EXP_INT_TABLE_MAX_INDEX]
Enclose large data table in nested static class so it's only loaded on first access.
Exponential over the range of 0 - 1 in increments of 2^-10 * exp(x/1024) = expFracTableA[x] + expFracTableB[x]. * 1024 = 2^10
Exponential over the range of 0 - 1 in increments of 2^-10 * exp(x/1024) = expFracTableA[x] + expFracTableB[x].
Enclose large data table in nested static class so it's only loaded on first access.
Extended precision logarithm table over the range 1 - 2 in increments of 2^-10.
Enclose the Cody/Waite reduction (used in "sin", "cos" and "tan").
k
remA
remB

javadoc.param: xa Argument.

method.name: CodyWaite
method.comment: Remainder is negative, so decrement k and try again.
This should only happen if the input is very close
to an even multiple of pi/2.

There are 52 bits in the mantissa of a double. For additional precision, the code splits double numbers into two parts, by clearing the low order 30 bits if possible, and then performs the arithmetic on each half separately.
